awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Secondary Organic Aerosol Formation from the Oxidation of Furan-compounds to Understand the Atmospheric Impacts of Biomass Burning Smoke
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is investigating emissions from biomass combustion and the implications of these emissions on air quality and climate.  Laboratory studies will be conducted to quantify the emissions of furan compounds (i.e., those containing a 4-carbon, 1-oxygen aromatic ring) from biomass burning and to determine the fate of these compounds in the atmosphere.  The results of this project can be incorporated into the modeling of the impacts of biomass burning chemistry on local, regional, and global scales.

The specific objectives of this project are to:n(1) Identify the organic compounds produced by the OH and NO3 oxidation of furan compounds and quantify their contribution to the SOA yield; (2) Determine how this oxidation chemistry, and the O3 and SOA produced, varies with NMOC/NOx ratio, temperature, and RH; (3) Use the above results to develop a detailed mechanism for the oxidation of these furan compounds in biomass burning plumes; and (4) Quantify how this new mechanism alters the predicted impacts of biomass burning on atmospheric O3 and PM2.5.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated emissions from biomass combustion and the implications of these emissions on air quality and climate. Biomass burning emits a large number of gaseous compounds, which can then undergo complex reactions in the atmosphere to form secondary organic aerosols (SOA), though the parameters controlling this process are not well understood. In this study, we conducted laboratory chamber studies to investigate SOA formation from three major furan compounds (i.e., those containing a 4-carbon, 1-oxygen aromatic ring) emitted from biomass burning, including furfural, 2-methylfuran, and 3-methylfuran. We investigated SOA formation from these compounds in both nighttime and daytime reaction conditions.

We demonstrated that nighttime oxidation of 3-methylfuran leads to SOA formation. More than half of the SOA mass is generated after complete depletion of 3-methylfuran, highlighting the importance of higher-generation or multiphase reactions to aerosol formation. A reaction mechanism is proposed based on the measured chemical species in the gas and particle phases. Results from this study provide detailed chemistry of 3-methylfuran oxidation that can improve our understanding of its impact on SOA and ozone formation in nighttime biomass burning plumes.

For daytime chemistry, our study first demonstrated the formation of brown carbon (light absorbing chemical species) in the photochemical oxidation of furan compounds. We found that furfural SOA has the strongest light absorption properties among all the furan compounds studied, driven by the presence of nitrogen-containing organic compounds. As furans are major emissions during biomass burning, these results suggest that daytime oxidation of furans can be an important source of brown carbon from biomass burning and impact climate. We further investigated how relative humidity impacts aerosol formation from furan compounds. We found that SOA formation is enhanced in the presence of higher relative humidity, driven by uptake of gas-phase compounds to the aqueous particles. These results highlight the important role of environmental conditions on SOA formation from biomass burning emissions.  

The research supported by this project contributed to the training of graduate and undergraduate students from the School of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences and the School of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering. Research outcomes have been disseminated via conference presentations, journal publications, as well as shared with undergraduate and graduate students in relevant courses. Results from this project provide new fundamental laboratory data to improve the simulation of the oxidation chemistry of biomass burning emissions and SOA formation, which would allow for more accurate predictions of their impacts on climate and human health.
